Fields.DialogueText: Who in the world is banging pots and pans at this hour?
C'est moi, Capitaine!
... Marseillaise? It was you?
Bon, you're awake. Help me with the rest of the crew.
Stop banging those pots and pans! I can't tell you how many weary crew members have stopped by my quarters to complain.
But it's time to wake up! Anyone still asleep is squandering the day.

Fields.MenuText: You may be right, but...
I'm inclined to agree with you, but I do want the crew to be well-rested.
Marseillaise, this is not your concern. There are procedures in place for this.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course I'm right!
What good is being well-rested if a Morgana kills you in your sleep?
Hmph. The laws of the old world are not long for this new one.
Look, Marseillaise, I'm just asking you to be a little more respectful of the other people on this ship. Can you do that?
Oui, Capitaine.
Good! Now... it does look like we have a few Morganas headed this direction.
Does this mean I can wake up the rest of the crew members?
... Yes.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Marseillaise! Didn't you tell me you were going to stop with the pots and pans? I thought we talked about this.
Capitaine, I understand that you are bothered by my actions, but...
There's no but. You're bothering everyone!
Liberty does not sleep! Will you let the people languish as the forces of darkness descend? Or will you allow me to stoke the fire of freedom burning in every heart?
You're stoking resentment.
Am I a threat to your power?
I'm too tired for this...
Too tired for me to wage a war against injustice?

Fields.MenuText: No, just too tired for all this nonsense! Are you sure you're not sleep-deprived?
Nobody's waging any kind of war if they keel over exhausted.
I agree with you, but there are better ways of going about this... like starting once we're all a little better rested.

Fields.DialogueText: I slept long enough, Capitaine!
Let others rise to take their place!
We will rest once the last Morgana is strangled with her own anchor chain!
Forcefully put. But I need you to dial back the insanity.
The old world cannot stand against these new threats. If preserving it is sanity, then let me be insane!
Takes one to beat one, I guess.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Now do you see? Revolution laughs at your schedules!
Um, Capitaine...
Ah, Marseillaise! You're calm today.
I wanted to apologize for my behavior. Not for my beliefs, of course... but I realize there are better ways to express my passion.
Your means weren't exactly universally beloved, no. But if you could temper yourself, you could rally the crew quite effectively.
Public speaking has always been one of my strong points. I could definitely do that.

Fields.MenuText: Oh! I wasn't expecting you to take to the idea so... enthusiastically.
Just... speak with some discernment. Encourage them, don't offend them.
I could even get a crate for you to stand on.

Fields.DialogueText: When the tyrants have taken everything else, only our voices will remain. They must be ready!
I wouldn't just call them lazy to their faces! Mais non! A good public speaker knows how to speak to their audience.
I would like that, Capitaine. Even small gestures can lead to great change.
But you know... I think I ought to hold off on any speeches for the time being. The crew needs a break.
I agree.
Aux armes, citoyens!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
One step at a time. Here's the next one.
The people can be pushed to revolution, but they cannot be dragged.
That, and nobody would talk to me in the mess.
Done a bit of soul-searching?
Marseillaise... what did I hear you shout just before we went into battle?
Quoi? Oh - "To arms, citizens!"
I see. It was short and sweet, just the way a call to battle should be. Got any more?
Battle cries? Nothing as good, I think. Although there are a few swear words which might make do. Ha!
Heh, no need to pull out the big guns. It's just an interesting thing to say with an international crew.
But I am especially proud to be French. To carry the tradition of the Revolution into this strange new age. Have I shown you the flag I carry into battle?
If it's important to you, I would be happy to. I don't know that I have anything I'm nearly that attached to.
Do you not?

Fields.MenuText: I have this ship. I suppose I'm pretty attached to it.
I have a few knick-knacks, but they're tiny. The larger something is, the more interesting it becomes.
Oh! I have an old, rusty anchor back home. For whatever reason, I'm pretty attached to that.

Fields.DialogueText: Me most of all. A funny thing, to be a Belle... the only bird that sustains its cage, eh?
C'est trop vrai! That must make we Belles the most interesting of all!
An old... rusty anchor?
*ALARM*
Looks like we'll have to hold off for now. But I want to know more.
Oui! I thought you'd never ask.
@BATTLE
I know, it doesn't sound that impressive. But if you saw it in person...
You don't need to speak the language to feel its truth.
Those are Morganas on the horizon. Marseillaise? Your battle cry?
Aux armes, citoyens!
@BATTLE
Whoa, whoa, whoa! What's going on here?
We don't know! She's been furious since the Morganas went down.
Cowards! Do you hear me, Morganas? You're just a bunch of cowards!
Marseillaise, Marsellaise! Why are you so angry?
Those Morganas are fearmongers, trying to intimidate us into submission. We'll never surrender to you! I'd rather die than surrender!
Whoa! Calm down, we defeated them.
Oui, but they'll be back. Again and again and again. Will you lose your resolve the fifth or sixth or seventh time? Will you surrender?

Fields.MenuText: Of course not! Surrendering shows weakness. I would just rather not die, if possible.
Well... I feel that in certain, extreme cases, it might be okay to surrender.
If surrendering will save the lives of my crew, I would be a fool not to consider the possibility.

Fields.DialogueText: Even if your only other option is surrender?
Absolutely not! Under no circumstances will I ever surrender to anyone!
To the Morganas!? You would be a fool to consider it at all!
I think you need to take a deep breath. Come on, let's go for a walk. We'll chat a little bit.
It is nothing to die, Capitaine. It is frightful not to live!
Well, while we're alive, why don't we retire to the mess. You must be hungry.
My appetite for blood is never sated!
Very hungry.
... Salted pork, if we've got it.
I hope I haven't scared anyone, Capitaine.
I don't think anyone's scared. Most people just don't have your... intensity.
A revolutionary spirit sleeps in every breast. I just happen to be a revolutionary spirit made flesh.
It's a good cause. But isn't it exhausting to stay so focused on one thing?
You didn't know? I feel like I've traded with most of the people on this ship. It's just little trinkets and necessities.
I guess I'm more oblivious than I thought. So what are you looking to trade?
I have a couple things with me. Let's see... I have this silver drachma, these amber earrings, and this pomander necklace.
Um... what is all of that stuff?
Well, the pomander is is a container for medicinal herbs. The drachma is the currency of Greece. And the earrings... well, those are self-explanatory.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't jewelry like the trappings of the ancien régime or something?
The drachma is interesting... do you know what those symbols mean?
Hmm... what do you have inside the pomander?

Fields.DialogueText: These are no gaudy jewels, Capitaine! Amber's healing qualities are well known to the common man.
Greek. I'll tell you if you'd like it!
Can you not smell the aroma? Cloves and cinnamon! And in a pinch, it makes delicious tea.
How about this... I've got a stash of weapons you can look through. Might come in handy for battles.
*ALARM*
I'll take you up on your offer, but let's wait until after the smoke clears.
Grrr... Aux armes, Capitaine. I'm about to get intense again.
@BATTLE
Even I don't spend all my time at revolution. Have I really never traded with you before?
... Traded?
Hello, Marseillaise! Ready to pick out your weapon?
You remembered?
Of course! A good captain never reneges on a promise.
This is the first weapon I've traded for. What have you got?
Well, I have a couple of rifles here, a few swords...
I want that sword!
Really?
Look at the metalwork - it's beautiful! How could I not appreciate it?
If you like it, it's yours.
You don't sound as impressed as I am. Maybe there's a reason you're letting it go so easy. Fine, what do you think is beautiful?

Fields.MenuText: Nature. Have you ever seen an ugly sunset?
People are beautiful. The life inside everyone gives me hope for the future.
Masterful art is beautiful. Paintings, literature, music... there are so many ways to express oneself.

Fields.DialogueText: Mais non. I haven't... but the metal for this sword had to come from nature, didn't it? Maybe even from the heavens!
That's highly sentimental of you, Capitaine. And absolutely right.
Smithing is art as well. Forging, folding, tempering metal... and it can make swords and plowshares alike!
I suppose the sword could be considered handsome as well.
I think I'll go hang it above my bed... It will look quite nice up there!
You'd better be quick about it.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
It might not be useful in battle, but it's a reminder of who we fight for. And it might come in handy if we get boarded.
Bonjour, Capitaine! ... Why are you staring at those earrings like that?
Oh, I think there might be some sort of insect trapped inside...
I believe there is. See here? That's a mosquito.
Isn't it amazing how something from so long ago can be preserved like this?
It's like a little window into history. We can't ask the people there what happened, but there will always be little clues.

Fields.MenuText: I'd love to have been present for the invention of Gutenberg's printing press.
I think I'd like to have seen what it was like during Biblical times.
I... almost wish I could have been around to see the dinosaurs.

Fields.DialogueText: Not the most exciting thing in the world. But it changed the way people share ideas.
That's a good answer, if broad. Some of those stories are just so interesting!
There's no reason to be so bashful, Capitaine! I'm sure such a time would have been thrilling.
It doesn't matter, though... No matter how much we wish we could see those times with our own eyes, we can't.
That just adds to the intrigue! If we knew everything, there would be no desire to explore. Uncertainty furthers the human mind.
Is that why you like learning about people?
*ALARM*
Maybe not in the way I'd thought. But if I didn't let things surprise me, I'd be as set in my ways as the ancien régime!
@BATTLE
I can't help it. Even the smallest possession raises big questions. "The people" is made up of people, after all.
The swords, for instance. I wouldn't have taken you for an enthusiast.
Not revolutionary enough for you?
Morganas are headed this way! Be at the ready!
@BATTLE
Whoa!
What's wrong, Capitaine!? I'm here!
Nothing, nothing's wrong. I dropped the drachma and it started rolling toward the edge of the ship, but I caught it.
That's a rare coin, Capitaine. You ought to be more careful with it.
I know, I know. I'll keep it in my quarters from now on.
Do you know what the inscription on the coin says?
Massalía?

Fields.MenuText: It's Greek to me. Literally.
The first letter is an M, so... money?
I wouldn't be surprised if it has some relation to a certain Belle's name...

Fields.DialogueText: That's all right. The inscription's fairly worn.
Money inscribed with the word money? Seems a little redundant, don't you think?
Ah, you're a clever one, aren't you, Capitaine?
Massalía was the name used by the ancient Greeks and Romans for the French city of Marseille.
My name, of course, refers to the French national anthem La Marseillaise, which was sung by volunteers from Marseille while they marched on Paris in 1792.
This coin has a lot of significance, then. Are you sure you... don't want it back?
No, no, I have others. Besides, it was a fair trade. I am very attached to my sword, after all.
I'm glad to hear it. Thank you, Marseillaise, for sharing part of your history with me.
C'est rien, Capitaine. That is what history is for.
Make the fallen proud! Avenge them or follow them!
Capitaine? What are you doing?
I decided to fill the pomander with my own mix of spices and herbs.
Mind if I give it a smell?
I don't know... it's no cloves-and-cinnamon blend.
Oh, don't be so bashful. Give it here.
Hmmm... Rosemary and... two, no three other things...

Fields.MenuText: So... what do you think?
Smells pretty good, doesn't it?
Hey, there's no reason to look so sour-faced.

Fields.DialogueText: It is... an interesting concoction of smells, Capitaine.
It's not a mix I would have ever thought of on my own...
Sour might not be the right word. It's just... not what I was expecting.
So you don't like it.
Non, non, that's not what I'm saying at all. Besides, it's your pomander now. As long as you like it, that's all that matters.
*ALARM*
You think the smell is potent enough it might drive away the Morganas?
Only one way to find out!
@BATTLE
Good to see you, Marseillaise! Did you come down here to get a bite to eat?
That is what one typically does in the galley.
I see someone is a little surly today...
Désolée - I'm not at my best when I haven't eaten. But all is solved when I reach the galley. A little salted pork puts me right back in order.
That's your favorite, eh?
That and bouillabaisse! But we can't really make that on a ship... Or can we? I'll have to talk to the cook.
What's your favorite food, Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: I like meat too! Although I'm not sure I'd be able to pick a favorite.
I like fresh vegetables. Sometimes I wish we had a garden aboard this ship.
I love all bread. Wheat, white, sourdough, rye, pumpernickel...

Fields.DialogueText: Delicious and filling. Fitting fuel for a fight!
Vegetables? Oh, boo.
Mmm... a nice slice of bread right out of the oven with a bowl of bouillabaisse? That would be splendid.
*ALARM*
Captain! We need you on the main deck!
Looks like food will have to wait until later. Turn that bad mood on the Morganas?
I hate fighting on an empty stomach...
@BATTLE
Can't run a revolution on an unbalanced diet.
C'est une blague, Capitain. I'm kidding. Vegetables can be delicious.
The Morganas are back! Get ready, crew!
@BATTLE
Wow, that took a lot out of me...
Capitaine! Are you all right? You look a little under the weather.
Little headache, little fatigue... I think I might just have a bug. It's nothing too serious.
Nothing too serious? Capitaine, you should take illnesses more seriously. Come with me! I have a whole host of medicinal plants in my cabin...

Fields.MenuText: Medicinal plants? Sounds a bit farfetched.
What plants are we talking about here?
I'd love to give it a shot!

Fields.DialogueText: Farfetched? Capitaine, I've witnessed the efficacy of these plants time and time again. They will help!
I'll give you an explanation on each!
I'm happy to hear you be so open-minded, Capitaine.
Come on, let's go back to my cabin; I'll show you what I have.
I didn't know you knew medicine.
Herbalism is a true discipline of the people. Just as nature possesses poisons, so does she offer remedies.
Some of them are hard to tell apart.
Worry not, Capitaine. I was born with this knowledge, and it grows every day. I'm my own perfect test subject, after all.
Belles get sick like people do?
Oui, to a degree. But unlike people, it takes more than a bad mushroom to kill a cruiser!
Are you feeling any better, Capitaine?
I am. I must say, it appears as if your plants did the trick.
No one believes me at first, but I always prove them wrong.
Now, here. Have a bite of this bitter orange.
Wow, that's... really bitter!
Heh! The look on your face... I wish we'd done this in front of a mirror.
Happy to entertain.
You'll be feeling like your old self by the end of the day. It's a wonder what nature can do for the human body, isn't it?

Fields.MenuText: Honestly, the less time I spend in nature, the happier I am. I'd rather spend the day inside than in a forest.
Nature can be quite helpful... but I would stop short of saying it's a cure all for all of life's ills.
Walking through forests and fields is probably what I miss most about dry land.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, the curse of the comfortable.
Certainly not all of them, Capitaine. But she holds secrets we would be wise not to forget.
There are always so many things to find! Nature can make life quite the adventure.
I have an idea. Why don't I teach you as much as I can about nature? I have all this knowledge, after all. I should pass it along to others.
I suppose a few lessons here and there wouldn't hurt. Sure, Marseillaise, I would be happy to learn.
*ALARM*
We'll start after the battle! Perhaps some feverfew for noise headaches...
@BATTLE
The Morganas are back! Let's make sure we give them a good- ACHOO!
@BATTLE
Capitaine! What have you done?
What? What's wrong? Is it the ship? Are we taking on water?
No, it's nothing like that! You're spreading your cold everywhere! Everyone is going to get sick.

Fields.MenuText: I think "everyone" might be too strong a word. Last I heard, five crew had been admitted to sick bay.
If the crew stay well hydrated and don't overwork themselves, they'll be fine.
If it keeps the Doctor out of our hair on the bridge it might not be all bad.

Fields.DialogueText: Five now. Five hundred in a few days.
That's not enough, Capitaine. A little water isn't enough to fight off disease!
Don't say such things, Capitaine! It's much too high a price to pay!
Instead of panicking, why don't you go to sick bay and offer to help the medics? Lend them some of your medicinal plants?
That... that's not a bad idea! Here, come with me! I'll need you to help me carry everything.
Of course. Need me to help with treatment?
I was being facetious, Marseillaise.
I... was just playing along?
Capitaine! Are you well?
I'm fine! Let's keep it that way!
Non. You're allowed as far as the sick bay doors. Safety first, Capitaine.
Phew... I think the entire crew is back to full health.
I can't believe how long it took to treat everyone. It felt like every time one person recovered, someone else would get sick!
You handled it well, Marseillaise. And the medical staff really did appreciate your help.
Their knowledge of natural medicine was subpar, at best. I hope they learned a few things from me.
Sorry. Just imagining the look on- never mind. I'm sure your herbal remedies made an impression.
Mais oui. I still have much to teach you, as well.
Then I'm ready to learn. Do you want to start the first lesson now?
Now? Well... sure! Where to begin? What do you know?

Fields.MenuText: Only what I've learned from you so far.
I have a little bit, but I'd like to know more.
I know quite a bit, but I'm sure you know more than I do.

Fields.DialogueText: A blank slate... Perfect.
Well, you've come to the right person. My knowledge goes back centuries.
Then let's not waste time on fundamentals. Straight to experimentation!
A self-sustaining herb garden for medicine... Would this happen to be part of your plan to incite revolution?
Different names for the same thing, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Ha! We're fighting one right now, Capitaine. The tyrant's duty is to keep the people divided. How better to do that than to steal the ocean herself?
As for after the Morganas... well, I hardly think you need my help with that. I find that the more you learn about the world, the more you want to share that knowledge.
In a world of scarcity and greed, what is more revolutionary than sharing?
*ALARM*
Survival?
... Heh.
Capitaine?
Marseillaise... I know you're the teacher, but must we sit on deck in subfreezing temperatures?
It's the best temperature for learning, Capitaine. A hot summer's day is fit only for upheaval and righteous anger.
What about something more temperate?
Of course, of course. Now, have you ever heard of Pytheas?
Pytheas?
He was a Greek geographer who discovered that the ocean's tides were controlled by the moon.

Fields.MenuText: Is this a history lesson, or a medicinal one?
No, I know who he was. I just didn't hear you clearly. Sorry.
I had no idea that the moon controlled the ocean.

Fields.DialogueText: The two are not mutually exclusive, Capitaine.
Très bien!
... How did you get to be Capitaine, again?
Now look how opposite the sea and moon are. One is grounded to the shore, while the other spins freely in the heavens. So different, yet so interconnected.
I suppose that's true for much of life. Everything is interconnected.
Exactly. Take, for example, those Morganas over there. They never seem to be separate from us, do they?
Not for a second. I guess it's time for another battle.
It's about to get hotter. You know what that means!
@BATTLE
Sarcasm, Marseillaise.
Speak plainly, Capitaine! We'll never get anywhere if we don't speak the same language.
Upheaval and righteous anger. Except the tyrants are comfortable and therefore off their guard.
Of course.
Marseillaise! I thought we were supposed to have another lesson. Are you just playing cards with the other crew members?
This is your next lesson. They're tarot cards.
Ah... what am I going to learn from these?
Come here. Pick a card.
This one, I guess.
Which one is it?

Fields.MenuText: The Hanged Man.
The Two of Cups.
The Four of Pentacles.

Fields.DialogueText: This particular card represents many things. For you, it signifies the trials you're facing in life; the difficulties you must endure.
See the two people on the card? They represent love and friendship. Perhaps a strong bond forming in your life.
This one suggests your possessions will become important to you soon. It is the surety of these material objects that will save you.
Hm... that's interesting. How accurate are your readings, typically?
They are not always clear at first, but they are never wrong. I'll have to do one for you sometime.
*ALARM*
Think those cards will tell us whether we'll win the coming battle?
They don't answer yes-or-no questions, Capitaine. But with you by my side, this one hardly bears asking.
@BATTLE
The Morganas are back! No time to waste, let's get to it!
@BATTLE
That was a rough battle... the Morganas do seem to be growing stronger.
Capitaine... I've damage to report.
Marseillaise! You're injured! What happened!?
There was a shell bound for my foredeck. I intercepted it.
You're barely on your feet! That looks like more than just a limp.
This is nothing, Capitaine. Better a hell of suffering than a hell of boredom.

Fields.MenuText: Where are your herbal remedies?
I'd prefer no hell at all.
You're heavier than I thought you'd be.

Fields.DialogueText: In my cabin, next to my bed. I'm just exhausted... but they will at least treat the symptoms.
Then you shouldn't have volunteered to be an angel.
Your bedside manner could use a little work, Capitaine.
Keep talking, Marseillaise. Whatever comes to your mind.
Aux armes, citoyens!
Capitaine... why...
What is it?
... Why rosemary?
Right, my pomander. You're never going to let that go, are you?
As long as it distracts me from the aches and bruises? Never.
Maybe there's something to your herbs after all.
Half the battle is in the mind, Capitaine.
And the other half?
Wreaking havoc on my ribs. Keep walking.
Do not worry. A little limp is no great thing.
Intercepted? You jumped in front of it!?
I have some salted pork for you, Marseillaise!
You didn't have to do that, Capitaine! Merci, merci.
A direct hit from a shell... I'm just happy you've made such a speedy recovery.
Well, it takes a lot to put us Belles out of commission. We're made of tough stuff. My crew, less so. That is why I had to take the hit where they could not.
But... you could have...
Mais oui, Capitaine. You can certainly help. I think it's time for a reading while we're here.
This again? All right. What do I do?
Just let me lay these out. We'll start with a basic three-card spread. That'll show us your question's past, present, and future. Let's flip the first one.

Fields.MenuText: The Eight of Wands.
The Moon.
The Hierophant.

Fields.DialogueText: And it's reversed. So what usually means a flurry of activity and opportunity might now represent hesitance.
That might speak to a personal uncertainty. Well, I'm glad that's in the past, eh?
Once upon a time, you were looking for some kind of inspiration, perhaps an alliance. Something good and merciful... and here she is, non?
I feel like I constantly fear the future, even if I expect something good from it.
Captain! The Morganas are up on the main deck! We need you, fast!
You see? Always a battle to be fought. The difference is in me, and in you.
Of course, Capitaine! We will finish this reading later.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Is there anything I can do to help?
Non, Capitaine, I could not have. That is why I was duty bound to intercept.
Ask yourself a question. No yes-or-no questions, now. The cards deal in self-reflection, not objective truth.
Got it. Now what?
Don't. Or at least, don't stop at fear. That's the point of these readings: to get you thinking about it in ways you might not have otherwise.
That makes me a little more confident. Are you up to the fight?
Marseillaise! Why did you invite... Whoa, that's a lot of paper.
Oh, I apologize for the mess! I was just looking for something in my notes...
Take all the time you need! I'll just... look around, I suppose.
Wait! I think I've found it! Ah, oui - Jupiter...
Capitaine! What do you think Jupiter represents?

Fields.MenuText: Well... it represents a planet.
Jupiter was...  the Roman counterpart to Zeus, wasn't he?
There were a few HMS Jupiters, a USS Jupiter, a couple of French Jupiters...

Fields.DialogueText: But there's more to Jupiter than that! There is more to everything than that.
C'est vrai, that is true! But we will save mythology for another day.
C'est vrai- those are all true. All fine vessels, but I am thinking of something less material.
I meant what Jupiter symbolizes in astrology - happiness, joviality, that sort of thing. Ah, well.
It was supposed to be visible tonight, but the fog will make it impossible to see. Next time it's visible, I'll let you know.
I'd... like that. I think.
Sir! We have Morganas headed this direction.
So much for happiness.
So much, indeed. What is worth smiling for is worth fighting for!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Capitaine! You're just in time! Come here, quick. See that bright star over there? That's Jupiter!
It's beautiful. What did you say it represented again?
Happiness, mostly. The word "jovial" literally means "pertaining to Jupiter."
How interesting...
Capitaine?
Yes, Marseillaise?
Say the first thing that comes to your mind.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think we'll ever see Jupiter in person?
Do you think Tullus Hostilius would agree that Jupiter inspired a lot of happiness?
Why does life so often consist of pain and suffering?

Fields.DialogueText: Absolutely. Humankind is driven by science. We will not stop until everything is explored.
Ha! Touché, Capitaine! But I might argue that Jupiter himself would have been happy enough after he burned Tullus' house down.
Struggle strengthens us. It prods us to grow. Just like my plants!
Now, as for the bearing of the heavens on your question...
Is there any?
I was with you for your herbs and your tarot. But... astrology?
A strange line to draw, non?
@BATTLE
Certainement, if one only looks.
Doesn't it seem a little... immaterial for our purposes?
Well, I am a warship; you, my capitaine. We're called upon to fight for what's right. And what's wrong is injustice and inequality, is it not?
Things are a little more complicated than that.
If the people were all equal, they would not fight among themselves. If we fight, it is to take back what has been denied us, as the Morganas would deny you the oceans... the coasts... the world.
But nature herself... the human soul and the stories it tells... those are inviolable. As long as you look for solace in these, your spirit is not truly lost.
*ALARM*
I never thought of it that way. It's like... always looking for something to read, isn't it? Something to keep your mind engaged.
Better a hell of suffering than a hell of boredom. Let us see if we cannot give the Morganas a hell of our own!
Everyone to your positions!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, look! It's Neptune!
... I'm afraid human eyes can't make it out unaided, Marseillaise.
That doesn't mean it isn't there. Do you think you can guess what it means?

Fields.MenuText: I'm guessing it represents peace and calm, like water.
Neptune... does it symbolize ferocity and passion?
I don't know... trustworthiness and compassion?

Fields.DialogueText: You're actually not far off!
Non, but I can see why your mind would go there!
Ah, very good! Perhaps we will make an astrologer of you yet.
Neptune is associated with a number of traits, including harmony and responsibility. But it also encompasses illusion; things like dreams and mysteries.
That is one complex planet.
Just like a person, don't you think? It's easy to think we know every facet of a person, when in reality, there are depths of personality we couldn't even imagine.
Just like people and Belles.
Ha! Yes, indeed, Capitaine. Now, then, look around Neptune and tell me if you see a pattern in the stars...
Fear nothing, citoyens! I have seen struggle and fire in this day, and beyond it the dawn of a day without either!
There's the alarm! Everyone, general quarters!
@BATTLE
Any new planets you can show me, Marseillaise?
Bien sûr! That's Saturn, right there!
Let me guess... you want me to tell you what it symbolizes?
Heh, you know me too well. What do you think?

Fields.MenuText: Saturn, Cronos - time?
Does it have to do with marriage and love? Because it's surrounded by rings?
I don't know... Trustworthiness and compassion?

Fields.DialogueText: Oui! Very well done, Capitaine!
That was cute, mais non.
That was Neptune, Capitaine! Different planet, different meaning.
So much of Saturn's traits are bound up in precision and time. Time is a very delicate thing. Seconds fall away without us even considering them.
Do you think we're wasting time right now?
Time spent learning is not a waste. There is visible labor and there is invisible labor. Remember that.
I will as long as you do. You're looking a little weary.
Thank you for looking out for me.
Likewise. The people have to stick together.
Time spent resting is also not a waste. How long have you been awake? You should get some sleep, Capitaine.
And so we will. That is what will win us this war.
I can see that look in your eyes, Marseillaise. You have something to teach me!
Don't I always? Venus is visible now!
Venus is an easy one - it's all about love, isn't it?
Exactly right! Venus symbolizes love, friendship, and emotional relationships of all types. It also symbolizes money and wealth. Does that make sense?

Fields.MenuText: Of course! Everyone knows that money and attraction are closely related.
It seems off. Love and money shouldn't mix.
It's a complicated question...

Fields.DialogueText: That's fair... though a little mercenary.
I agree with you, but the world is not always so pure of heart. Or of purse, as the case may be.
Isn't everything, if you look at it for long enough?
The question of money aside... love, in all its forms, is so important. It's love that drives us to take up arms, to fight the Morganas and defend our homelands.
They're useful. You just have to know when to turn them off.
Just keep your eyes set on the enemy and your heart set on the salted pork.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Love of freedom, family, friends... Money. Hmm. Maybe Venus is two sides of a coin. Love drives us to great things. Whether it's the right kind of love... whether those things are good...
It's a different question, isn't it? Now you understand the rages I work myself into.
Perhaps after this stretch of sea has been made safe, non?
Beautiful outside, isn't it?
Mais oui! It's glorious.
Is the sky telling you anything?
The moon always has something important to say.

Fields.MenuText: So the man in the moon does have a voice?

Fields.DialogueText: You know as well as I do that there's no man in the moon!
What do you think is out beyond it?
That's what it means to me, anyway. What about you?

Fields.MenuText: I think that's right. With you Belles by our side, there's no way we can lose.
Whatever world we build, I want to build it with you.
Do you think people will go there one day?
I would hope so. It's been with us forever.

Fields.DialogueText: That may be, Capitaine. But I would hope we set things straight here first. Progress for a few is progress for none.
And will be for some time after we're gone. Small wonder humans started listening to her.
Any number of things, Capitaine. I believe it was not so long ago that another planet was discovered.
Pluto. That's to do with the underworld, isn't it? Isn't that... bad?
Still bad.
Well, it also means wealth... change... renewal. I believe the Great War occurred right around the time it entered the constellation Cancer.
Different. But if a new planet were to be discovered, I would say that this one was apt for this time. The world changes, and we must stand together to see that it's for the better.
As long as there's hope keeping us going, we never will.
Heh... You know, it's said that the future belongs to hearts even more than it does to minds.
By whom?
Someone who paid very close attention to the world and allowed himself to hope. We should do the same. Together.
